creator: tigeryell99@yahoo.com
text:
If a response to an Http GET contains a zip file, the ResponseData stores it as a String instead of as CDATA. This causes an invalid character error when trying to parse the XML jtl file. 

Running the Testcase via the commandline and creating XML jtl files for each Testcase.

Hello,
Could you provide some test case ?
Thanks
creator: p.mouawad@ubik-ingenierie.com

text:
Created attachment 32606
JMeter script

Example JMeter script that gets a zip file from a server. 

The real problem is not in the script, the issue is when running the script via the Command line. The jtl that it generates is not valid xml and therefore XML parsing tools cannot read it.
creator: tigeryell99@yahoo.com
tigeryell99@yahoo.com
text:
If you run the Testcase I uploaded via the command line like so: 

java -jar "/<JMETERPATH>/apache-jmeter-2.12/bin/ApacheJMeter.jar" -n --propfile "/<PROPERTIES_PATH>/Jmeter.properties" --jmeterproperty host=10.47.18.133 -l "/<OUTPUT_PATH>/GetBillingData.jtl" -j "/<OUTPUT_PATH>/GetBillingData.log" -t "/<JMX_PATH>/GetBillingData.jmx"

Then the GetBillingData.JTL file it spits out is not valid. The ResponseData looks something like this: <responseData class="java.lang.String">PK�&# .... </responseData>

Even though the httpSample has the header "Content-Type: application/zip".


******** Settings in the Properties file******
jmeter.save.saveservice.output_format=xml
# timestamp_format is not currently supported for xml output
#jmeter.save.saveservice.timestamp_format=HH:mm:ss

# ****true when field should be saved; false otherwise
# assertion_results_failure_message only affects CSV output
jmeter.save.saveservice.assertion_results_failure_message=true
#
jmeter.save.saveservice.data_type=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.label=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.response_code=true
# response_data is not currently supported for CSV output
jmeter.save.saveservice.response_data=true
# Save ResponseData for failed samples
jmeter.save.saveservice.response_data.on_error=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.response_message=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.successful=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.thread_name=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.time=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.subresults=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.assertions=true
#jmeter.save.saveservice.latency=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.samplerData=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.responseHeaders=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.requestHeaders=true
#jmeter.save.saveservice.encoding=false
#jmeter.save.saveservice.bytes=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.url=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.filename=true
jmeter.save.saveservice.hostname=true
#jmeter.save.saveservice.thread_counts=false
#jmeter.save.saveservice.sample_count=false
#jmeter.save.saveservice.idle_time=false

# Put the start time stamp in logs instead of the end
sampleresult.timestamp.start=false

creator: p.mouawad@ubik-ingenierie.com
text:
Hi,
This is the format used by XStream.
If you want the XML responsed , you can use :
http://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/component_reference.html#Save_Responses_to_a_file


It will save the response as XML.
